pretty much our basic kit and you can see I have all different all different

so most dungeons they're you know they're made out of stone there might be
some wood and a little metal in the dungeon so that's why I have these
colors so I've got black now black you can mix with any of the other colors if
you need to also I use it for shading on the walls of most of my tiles to give it
more of a 3d look on the tile so black is good you can also get larger bottles
of black which I've suggest cuz you're gonna use a lot of black so you know get
a big bottle of black if you can and then we move on to gray now I've got two
types of gray I've got a darker gray and a lighter gray now the darker gray I'm
I've used for projects where I'm not texture painting something with a

highlighting tiles you see means we like highlight the edges of the tiles and
things to kind of that just kind of gives us some dimension since it's only
you know the wall is only short it helps to bring the wall up too to give the
illusion that the wall is taller so the highlight really helps with that
now here I've got some Browns I've got a dark brown and usually it's just like
burnt umber and then I have a golden brown and this is just a spiced brown it
really doesn't matter what combination you get get just get it make sure you
get a dark brown it doesn't have to be burnt umber these colors you don't have

different colors of brown because you don't want to make everything the same

than things that are like the soil so I might I use the dark brown and paint
everything first and then I will use say if it's a wood Brown I might use this
golden brown to give it some highlights and if it's like dirt I might use a

shining you know shiny you know bumper or something you know it's like this is
an old dungeon you don't want it to be all shiny and new you want it to look
old so the gunmetal really makes it look like an old you know like Bandon or

so these are these are the basic colors you want so I mean it's not very many

all right next up we have a water kit so if you're going to do some kind of water
that's not brown or murky you'll want this kit so basically I've got a dark
blue this is a midnight blue I've got a lighter blue this is called regency blue
but like I said you could use any blue as long as it's lighter than this one
and then I have white so you can always mix these two together to make lighter
or darker areas so generally what I will do is when I do a water area and I want
it to be the bluish color or not like some Bracken
you know Oh pool which you can always add black to if you wanted it or Brown
actually Brown would be better what I'll do is I'll start I'll use a very wet
application and I'll start with the dark blue and then while that's still wet
I'll use the lighter blue and do the edges so I'll do like the center with a
darker blue and now I'll do on the on the edges the lighter blue so it gives
the illusion that the pool is going down like it's deeper in the middle than it
is on the edges so that's kind of a nice effect and also the water if you do some
if the water is maybe splashing against the side or something or you want some
lighter areas you could are cresting water or something you could use the
